medical: EXAM: CT head without contrast. INDICATIONS: Assaulted, positive loss of consciousness, rule out bleed. TECHNIQUE: CT examination of the head was performed without intravenous contrast administration. There are no comparison studies. FINDINGS: There are no abnormal extraaxial fluid collections. There is no midline shift or mass effect. Ventricular system demonstrates no dilatation. There is no evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage. The calvarium is intact. There is a laceration in the left parietal region of the scalp without underlying calvarial fractures. The mastoid air cells are clear. IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial process.
layman:
EXAM: CT scan of the head without contrast.  
INDICATIONS: The patient was assaulted, lost consciousness, and the scan is to check for a brain bleed.  

TECHNIQUE: A CT scan of the head was done without using any contrast dye. No previous scans were compared.  

FINDINGS:  
- No abnormal fluid collections outside the brain.  
- No shift of the brain’s center or pressure from a mass.  
- The brain’s fluid spaces (ventricles) are normal.  
- No signs of a new brain bleed.  
- The skull is intact.  
- There is a cut on the left side of the scalp, but no skull fracture.  
- The mastoid air cells (behind the ears) are clear.  

IMPRESSION: No new or urgent brain problem.
